channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Private ispace Moon landing fails: researchers are investigating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01441-y

Mission control have been unable to re-establish contact with the M1 spacecraft, but early signs suggest it crash landed on the lunar surface.
item.dc:title: Private ispace Moon landing fails: researchers are investigating
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Rewilding the planet: how seven artificial islands could help a dying Dutch lake
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01370-w

An archipelago constructed of sand and mud is bringing new life to a dead lake but can this bold experiment have a lasting impact?
item.dc:title: Rewilding the planet: how seven artificial islands could help a dying Dutch lake
item.dc:creator: Aisling Irwin

item.title: Are repeat COVID infections dangerous? What the science says
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01371-9

Researchers disagree over how bad it is to be reinfected, and whether COVID-19 can cause lasting changes to the immune system.
item.dc:title: Are repeat COVID infections dangerous? What the science says
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: Change YourView
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01318-0

The world is just enough.
item.dc:title: Change YourView
item.dc:creator: Matt Tighe

item.title: Goldfish headgear reveals secrets of fish navigation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01427-w

Unprecedented pattern of brain activity is recorded in freely swimming fish.
item.dc:title: Goldfish headgear reveals secrets of fish navigation

item.title: Full closure of high seas would triple the benefits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01394-2

Full closure of high seas would triple the benefits
item.dc:title: Full closure of high seas would triple the benefits
item.dc:creator: Crow White

item.title: From the archive: how several artists’ works mimic impressions made on the eye’s retina, and the curious effects of blue glass on colour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01354-w

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: how several artists’ works mimic impressions made on the eye’s retina, and the curious effects of blue glass on colour

item.title: IPCC: expand into a panel on sustainability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01392-4

IPCC: expand into a panel on sustainability
item.dc:title: IPCC: expand into a panel on sustainability
item.dc:creator: Thomas Schaubroeck

item.title: Green transition: create a European energy agency
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01393-3

Green transition: create a European energy agency
item.dc:title: Green transition: create a European energy agency
item.dc:creator: Simone Tagliapietra
Georg Zachmann

item.title: Ancient Norse on Greenland imported wood from distant shores
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01412-3

Settlers brought in hemlock and other types of timber much earlier than previously realized.
item.dc:title: Ancient Norse on Greenland imported wood from distant shores

item.title: The gene-therapy revolution risks stalling if we don’t talk about drug pricing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01389-z

Regulation and new intellectual property laws are needed to reduce the cost of gene-editing treatments and fulfil their promise to improve human health.
item.dc:title: The gene-therapy revolution risks stalling if we don’t talk about drug pricing

item.title: Suburbs are a climate disaster, but they can be redeemed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01369-3

With a radical approach to planning, suburbs in the United States can be made affordable, liveable and climate friendly.
item.dc:title: Suburbs are a climate disaster, but they can be redeemed
item.dc:creator: Dana Cuff

item.title: How Rosalind Franklin was let down by DNA’s dysfunctional team
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01390-6

The story of how the structure of DNA was found is one of team science from which one member was unforgivably excluded.
item.dc:title: How Rosalind Franklin was let down by DNA’s dysfunctional team

item.title: What Rosalind Franklin truly contributed to the discovery of DNA’s structure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01313-5

Franklin was no victim in how the DNA double helix was solved. An overlooked letter and an unpublished news article, both written in 1953, reveal that she was an equal player.
item.dc:title: What Rosalind Franklin truly contributed to the discovery of DNA’s structure
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cobb
Nathaniel Comfort

item.title: Addendum: Agrochemicals interact synergistically to increase bee mortality
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05997-7

Addendum: Agrochemicals interact synergistically to increase bee mortality
item.dc:title: Addendum: Agrochemicals interact synergistically to increase bee mortality
item.dc:creator: Harry Siviter
Emily J. Bailes
Callum D. Martin
Thomas R. Oliver
Julia Koricheva
Ellouise Leadbeater
Mark J. F. Brown

item.title: First up-close images of Mars’s little-known moon Deimos
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01422-1

Images from the UAE’s Hope mission suggest that the moonlet’s composition is similar to that of the red planet’s surface.
item.dc:title: First up-close images of Mars’s little-known moon Deimos
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: I explore my people’s sacred space to protect biodiversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01374-6

Zoleka Filander leads research in South African waters to shield vulnerable marine life and honour her Indigenous community.
item.dc:title: I explore my people’s sacred space to protect biodiversity
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: Bipolar impact and phasing of Heinrich-type climate variability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05875-2

Ice-core data show that extreme iceberg discharge events in the North Atlantic had no detectable impact on Greenland temperatures but are synchronous with abrupt acceleration of Antarctic warming.
item.dc:title: Bipolar impact and phasing of Heinrich-type climate variability
item.dc:creator: Kaden C. Martin
Christo Buizert
Jon S. Edwards
Michael L. Kalk
Ben Riddell-Young
Edward J. Brook
Ross Beaudette
Jeffrey P. Severinghaus
Todd A. Sowers

item.title: Diving deep: the centuries-long quest to explore the deepest ocean
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01372-8

Schemes to dive to the bottom of the sea have a surprisingly long history — but a book shows how science has rarely been the motivation.
item.dc:title: Diving deep: the centuries-long quest to explore the deepest ocean
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: ‘Truly gobsmacked’: Ancient-human genome count surpasses 10,000
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01403-4

The majority of sequences come from people who lived in Western Eurasia, but samples from other regions are on the rise.
item.dc:title: ‘Truly gobsmacked’: Ancient-human genome count surpasses 10,000
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: An evolutionary route to warning coloration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01356-8

Bright colours that signal toxicity can deter predators, but how such colours initially evolve without first endangering conspicuous organisms is a contentious issue. Analysis of amphibians offers an answer to the puzzle.
item.dc:title: An evolutionary route to warning coloration
item.dc:creator: Tim Caro

item.title: JWST spots planetary building blocks in a surprising galaxy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01418-x

Planets might be more common throughout the Universe than previously thought, suggest results from the James Webb Space Telescope.
item.dc:title: JWST spots planetary building blocks in a surprising galaxy
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero

item.title: Say what? The principal investigators who pass down wisdom through humour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01373-7

Wit can convey important truths about critical thinking and the scientific method, especially when group leaders poke fun at themselves in the process.
item.dc:title: Say what? The principal investigators who pass down wisdom through humour
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: Private Moon mission prepares for historic landing attempt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01423-0

The Japanese-built ispace lander, carrying a rover from the United Arab Emirates, could be the first private venture to land on the lunar surface.
item.dc:title: Private Moon mission prepares for historic landing attempt
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Daily briefing: Neuroscience editors resign over cost of APCs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01430-1

More than 40 editors from two neuroscience journals quit in protest against author fees. Plus, Tasmanian devil facial tumours emerged a decade before detection and why we all misremember the same stuff.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Neuroscience editors resign over cost of APCs
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Daily briefing: First close-up images of tiny Mars moonlet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01438-7

Stunning shots of Mars’s moon Deimos hint at secrets of its formation. Plus, a milestone in ancient-human DNA and scientists taught parrots to video call each other.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: First close-up images of tiny Mars moonlet
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: An easy-to-swallow pill monitors X-ray dosage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01284-7

Device could enable doctors to calibrate the treatment of people receiving radiotherapy for certain tumours.
item.dc:title: An easy-to-swallow pill monitors X-ray dosage

item.title: Flu edges closer to spilling from dogs into humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01278-5

Some H3N2 strains of influenza infecting dogs in Asia have developed ominous mutations.
item.dc:title: Flu edges closer to spilling from dogs into humans

item.title: Editors quit top neuroscience journal to protest against open-access charges
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01391-5

Members of the departing editorial teams say that the fees to publish articles are unsustainable.
item.dc:title: Editors quit top neuroscience journal to protest against open-access charges
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: How deep brain stimulation is helping people with severe depression
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01375-5

Neurologist Helen Mayberg describes a treatment that tunes a circuit in the brain with an implanted device.
item.dc:title: How deep brain stimulation is helping people with severe depression
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: Daily briefing: Cannabis gives worms the munchies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01420-3

Caenorhabditis elegans spends a lot of time eating after soaking in an endocannabinoid bath. Plus, stem-cell malfunction causes grey hair and how to prepare your lab for natural disasters.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Cannabis gives worms the munchies
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: University of Oxford bans intimate relations between students and staff
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01402-5

UK institution joins many universities worldwide in enacting policies to protect students’ rights and prevent power abuses.
item.dc:title: University of Oxford bans intimate relations between students and staff
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Human–AI team halves cost of designing step in microchip fabrication
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01353-x

Engineers and algorithms have competed in a virtual test to design a step in the process of manufacturing computer chips. Pairing human expertise with computational efficiency proves most cost-effective, but only when the timing is right.
item.dc:title: Human–AI team halves cost of designing step in microchip fabrication
item.dc:creator: Ying-Lang Wang
Mao-Chih Huang

item.title: How CubeSats could harm the ozone layer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01281-w

The proliferation of miniature satellites — and a possible switch to iodine exhaust — could have unintended consequences.
item.dc:title: How CubeSats could harm the ozone layer

item.title: Floods claim more lives where inequality reigns
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01280-x

Flood mortality rates are far higher in countries with larger income disparities.
item.dc:title: Floods claim more lives where inequality reigns

item.title: Genetic map of Tasmanian devil cancers hints at their future evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01349-7

Most detailed analysis yet pinpoints the contagious tumours’ origins.
item.dc:title: Genetic map of Tasmanian devil cancers hints at their future evolution
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Daily briefing: Landmark SpaceX Starship launch test ends early
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01382-6

SpaceX’s enormous Starship vehicle launched successfully but blew up during a planned separation. Plus, the big-handed ‘homunculus’ model of the brain is flawed and the US looks to approve MDMA for PTSD.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Landmark SpaceX Starship launch test ends early
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: White House to tap cancer leader Monica Bertagnolli as new NIH director
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01378-2

Long-awaited decision comes more than a year after Francis Collins resigned as director of the largest public funder of biomedical research in the world.
item.dc:title: White House to tap cancer leader Monica Bertagnolli as new NIH director
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov
Heidi Ledford

item.title: Disasters happen — here’s how to soften their blow in the lab
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01317-1

Preparation and flexibility are key to a smooth recovery.
item.dc:title: Disasters happen — here’s how to soften their blow in the lab
item.dc:creator: Alla Katsnelson

item.title: Drugs give biology’s favourite worms the munchies too
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01376-4

Experiments with C. elegans suggest that the mechanism by which cannabis affects appetite evolved 500 million years ago.
item.dc:title: Drugs give biology’s favourite worms the munchies too
item.dc:creator: Elissa Welle

item.title: Australian researchers welcome plan to curb politicians’ power to veto grants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01379-1

Under new proposals, ministerial intervention would be limited to projects where national security is at stake.
item.dc:title: Australian researchers welcome plan to curb politicians’ power to veto grants
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Comb jellies’ unique fused neurons challenge evolution ideas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01381-7

Fused neurons suggest ctenophores’ nervous system evolved independently of that in other animals.
item.dc:title: Comb jellies’ unique fused neurons challenge evolution ideas
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: SpaceX Starship: launch of biggest-ever rocket ends with explosion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01377-3

The SpaceX rocket made it partially through its first full test. It could change astrophysics and astronomy, as well as ferry people to the Moon and Mars.
item.dc:title: SpaceX Starship: launch of biggest-ever rocket ends with explosion
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Strain-promoted reactions of 1,2,3-cyclohexatriene and its derivatives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06075-8

Strain-promoted reactions of 1,2,3-cyclohexatriene and its derivatives
item.dc:title: Strain-promoted reactions of 1,2,3-cyclohexatriene and its derivatives
item.dc:creator: Andrew V. Kelleghan
Ana S. Bulger
Dominick C. Witkowski
Neil K. Garg

item.title: Insufficient evidence for non-neutrality of synonymous mutations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05865-4

Insufficient evidence for non-neutrality of synonymous mutations
item.dc:title: Insufficient evidence for non-neutrality of synonymous mutations
item.dc:creator: Leonid Kruglyak
Andreas Beyer
Joshua S. Bloom
Jan Grossbach
Tami D. Lieberman
Christopher P. Mancuso

item.title: A smarter way to melt down plastics?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01348-8

Repeated flash-heating provides a new way to depolymerise plastics, and the latest from the Nature Briefing.
item.dc:title: A smarter way to melt down plastics?
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Ultrafiltration separation of Am(VI)-polyoxometalate from lanthanides
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05840-z

A new strategy to separate radioactive americium from lanthanides based on complexation with polyoxometalates and ultrafiltration technique is highly efficient and rapid, does not involve any organic components and requires minimal energy input.
item.dc:title: Ultrafiltration separation of Am(VI)-polyoxometalate from lanthanides
item.dc:creator: Hailong Zhang

item.title: Depolymerization of plastics by means of electrified spatiotemporal heating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05845-8

A depolymerization method is described that uses electrified spatiotemporal heating to selectively generate monomers from the commodity plastics polypropylene and poly(ethylene terephthalate), allowing control over the pyrolysis of plastic waste and reducing the formation of side products.
item.dc:title: Depolymerization of plastics by means of electrified spatiotemporal heating

item.title: The Smc5/6 complex is a DNA loop-extruding motor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05963-3

Using single-molecule imaging, the authors show that Smc5/6 forms DNA loops by extrusion, which establishes DNA loop extrusion as a conserved mechanism among eukaryotic SMC complexes.
item.dc:title: The Smc5/6 complex is a DNA loop-extruding motor
item.dc:creator: Biswajit Pradhan
Takaharu Kanno
Miki Umeda Igarashi

Martin Dieter Baaske

Eugene Kim

item.title: Quantum critical dynamics in a 5,000-qubit programmable spin glass
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05867-2

Using a quantum annealing processor to study three-dimensional spin glasses demonstrates an accurate large-scale quantum simulation of critical dynamics and a scaling advantage over analogous classical methods for energy optimization.
item.dc:title: Quantum critical dynamics in a 5,000-qubit programmable spin glass
item.dc:creator: Andrew D. King

item.title: A 3D printable alloy designed for extreme environments
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05893-0

The authors develop a new oxide-dispersion-strengthened NiCoCr-based alloy using a model-driven alloy design approach and laser-based additive manufacturing, showing how such designs can provide superior compositions using far fewer resources than previous methods.
item.dc:title: A 3D printable alloy designed for extreme environments

item.title: Lesion recognition by XPC, TFIIH and XPA in DNA excision repair
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05959-z

Cryo-electron microscopy structures reveal how XPC recognizes DNA lesions and recruits XPA and the TFIIH core complex for lesion verification in nucleotide excision repair.
item.dc:title: Lesion recognition by XPC, TFIIH and XPA in DNA excision repair
item.dc:creator: Jinseok Kim
Chia-Lung Li

Wei Yang

item.title: CTCF is a DNA-tension-dependent barrier to cohesin-mediated loop extrusion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05961-5

CTCF is sufficient to block loop extruding cohesin in a DNA tension dependent manner, and induces loop extrusion direction switching and loop shrinkage.
item.dc:title: CTCF is a DNA-tension-dependent barrier to cohesin-mediated loop extrusion
item.dc:creator: Iain F. Davidson

item.title: COVID-19 amplified racial disparities in the US criminal legal system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05980-2

A study shows that, although the number of incarcerated people in the USA decreased during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic, the fraction of incarcerated Black and Latino individuals increased.
item.dc:title: COVID-19 amplified racial disparities in the US criminal legal system
item.dc:creator: Brennan Klein

item.title: PI3Kβ controls immune evasion in PTEN-deficient breast tumours
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05940-w

A mouse model of invasive breast cancer in which Pten and Trp53 are simultaneously inactivated links PTEN loss with STAT3 activation and indicates that immune escape in PTEN-null tumours is mediated by PI3Kβ.
item.dc:title: PI3Kβ controls immune evasion in PTEN-deficient breast tumours

item.title: A somato-cognitive action network alternates with effector regions in motor cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05964-2

Functional MRI﻿ studies across ages show that the classic homunculus of the motor cortex in humans is in fact discontinuous, alternating with action control-linked regions termed the somato-cognitive action network.
item.dc:title: A somato-cognitive action network alternates with effector regions in motor cortex

item.title: Export of defensive glucosinolates is key for their accumulation in seeds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05969-x

Arabidopsis thaliana UMAMIT uniporters facilitate glucosinolate efflux from biosynthetic cells along the electrochemical gradient into the apoplast, in which the high-affinity H+-coupled glucosinolate importers GLUCOSINOLATE TRANSPORTERS (GTRs) load them into the phloem for translocation to the seeds.
item.dc:title: Export of defensive glucosinolates is key for their accumulation in seeds
item.dc:creator: Deyang Xu
Niels Christian Holm Sanden
Line Lykke Hansen
Zeinu Mussa Belew
Svend Roesen Madsen
Lasse Meyer
Morten Egevang Jørgensen
Pascal Hunziker
Dorottya Veres
Christoph Crocoll
Alexander Schulz
Hussam Hassan Nour-Eldin
Barbara Ann Halkier

item.title: pH-dependent water permeability switching and its memory in MoS<sub>2</sub> membranes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05849-4

We demonstrate the memory effects and stimuli-regulated transport of molecules through an intelligent, phase-changing MoS2 membrane in response to external pH, a phenomenon unique to the 1T′ phase of MoS2.
item.dc:title: pH-dependent water permeability switching and its memory in MoS<sub>2</sub> membranes
item.dc:creator: C. Y. Hu
A. Achari
P. Rowe
H. Xiao
S. Suran
Z. Li
K. Huang
C. Chi
C. T. Cherian
V. Sreepal
P. D. Bentley
A. Pratt
N. Zhang
K. S. Novoselov
A. Michaelides
R. R. Nair

item.title: Mirusviruses link herpesviruses to giant viruses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05962-4

A phylogeny-guided genome-resolved metagenomic analysis of DNA viruses in the ocean reveals atypical plankton-infecting relatives of herpesviruses that form a putative new phylum dubbed Mirusviricota.
item.dc:title: Mirusviruses link herpesviruses to giant viruses
item.dc:creator: Morgan Gaïa
Lingjie Meng
Eric Pelletier
Patrick Forterre
Chiara Vanni
Antonio Fernandez-Guerra
Olivier Jaillon
Patrick Wincker
Hiroyuki Ogata
Mart Krupovic
Tom O. Delmont

item.title: Dedifferentiation maintains melanocyte stem cells in a dynamic niche
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05960-6

Local microenvironmental cues modulate melanocyte stem cells, which control hair pigmentation, to enter different differentiation states, shifting between hair follicle stem cell and transit-amplifying compartments, a process that is different to other self-renewing systems.
item.dc:title: Dedifferentiation maintains melanocyte stem cells in a dynamic niche
item.dc:creator: Qi Sun
Wendy Lee
Hai Hu
Tatsuya Ogawa
Sophie De Leon
Ioanna Katehis
Chae Ho Lim
Makoto Takeo
Michael Cammer
M. Mark Taketo
Denise L. Gay
Sarah E. Millar
Mayumi Ito

item.title: Metal-oxide cages open up strategy for processing nuclear waste
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01019-8

The ability to separate the radioactive element americium from spent nuclear fuel would lower the long-term hazards of nuclear waste. An inorganic molecular cage that selectively binds to americium opens up a separation strategy.
item.dc:title: Metal-oxide cages open up strategy for processing nuclear waste
item.dc:creator: May Nyman
Gauthier Deblonde

item.title: Racial inequalities deepened in US prisons during COVID
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01311-7

The proportion of incarcerated people who were Black or Latino increased during the pandemic, mainly because of sentencing differences.
item.dc:title: Racial inequalities deepened in US prisons during COVID
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero

item.title: Yo-yoing stem cells defy dogma to maintain hair colour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00918-0

The observation that melanocyte stem cells migrate up and down the hair follicle, differentiating into melanocytes and then returning to a stem-cell identity, calls into question long-held assumptions about adult stem cells.
item.dc:title: Yo-yoing stem cells defy dogma to maintain hair colour
item.dc:creator: Carlos Galvan
William E. Lowry

item.title: Daily briefing: Immunize the financial system against ‘superspreader’ bank failures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01319-z

Ecology and infectious-disease science can help avert financial crises. Plus, Earth’s giant kelp forests are worth $500 billion a year and the amateur variant-sleuths helping scientists to track SARS-CoV-2.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Immunize the financial system against ‘superspreader’ bank failures
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Mars needs poets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01302-8

The rhythm of life.
item.dc:title: Mars needs poets
item.dc:creator: Todd Honeycutt

item.title: Famous ‘homunculus’ brain map redrawn to include complex movements
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01312-6

Textbook homunculus diagram depicts how the brain controls individual body parts — the revamp could improve treatments for brain injury.
item.dc:title: Famous ‘homunculus’ brain map redrawn to include complex movements
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: US could soon approve MDMA therapy — opening an era of psychedelic medicine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01296-3

Perceptions have shifted dramatically in the past few years on the therapeutic value of illicit drugs such as ecstasy. But questions still linger about what FDA approval might look like.
item.dc:title: US could soon approve MDMA therapy — opening an era of psychedelic medicine
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: DART’s data verify its smashing success at deflecting asteroid moon Dimorphos
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01020-1

A strategy for deflecting asteroids on a path towards Earth has passed its first test. The results confirm predictions about how asteroids respond to impact — and offer useful insights.
item.dc:title: DART’s data verify its smashing success at deflecting asteroid moon Dimorphos
item.dc:creator: Coralie D. Adam

item.title: A redrawn map for the human motor cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01350-0

The human brain’s motor cortex is often regarded as a linear map with discrete sections, each controlling different parts of the body. The discovery that portions of the motor cortex have other functions points to a different type of map.
item.dc:title: A redrawn map for the human motor cortex
item.dc:creator: David A. Leopold

item.title: Enzyme lights dual fires to promote cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01025-w

Tumours with certain cancer-driving mutations are difficult to treat. A discovery that one enzyme both controls proliferation and suppresses anticancer immune defences presages the exploration of new cancer-therapy strategies.
item.dc:title: Enzyme lights dual fires to promote cancer
item.dc:creator: Anghesom Ghebremedhin
Judith A. Varner

item.title: Science strengthened banks — but how long will stability last?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01291-8

The results of influential studies are being used to monitor the world’s banking system amid continuing concerns over bank failures.
item.dc:title: Science strengthened banks — but how long will stability last?
item.dc:creator: Mark Buchanan

item.title: Strengthen links between science and high finance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01294-5

Influential studies have helped regulators to spot problems at banks and step in before they spread. But, as the events of the past month show, stability must not be allowed to breed complacency.
item.dc:title: Strengthen links between science and high finance

item.title: Plastic polymers split into reusable monomers using an electrical heating method
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00947-9

An innovative approach has been developed to break down plastic polymers into their monomer building blocks. It uses a continuous melting, wicking, vaporization and reaction process in a porous carbon-bilayer structure, and can convert two model plastic polymers to their monomers at high yields without a catalyst.
item.dc:title: Plastic polymers split into reusable monomers using an electrical heating method

item.title: COVID pandemic increased racial disparities in US prison populations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01023-y

A public data set on the size and racial composition of US prison populations has been generated. Its analysis indicates how biases in sentencing lengths shape prisons’ racial make-up in the United States.
item.dc:title: COVID pandemic increased racial disparities in US prison populations
item.dc:creator: Jessica M. Eaglin

item.title: Rethink changing species names that honour real people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01276-7

Rethink changing species names that honour real people
item.dc:title: Rethink changing species names that honour real people
item.dc:creator: Guilherme S. T. Garbino
